abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project was
            unsatisfactory, with substantial negligible objectives,
            concerning irrigation costs recovery, output pricing, and,
            public expenditure priorities. However, the project was
            successful in moving the agricultural policy agenda forward.
            The Bank failed to deliver appropriate preparation and
            supervision of the project, due to several staff changes,
            making a sustained dialogue difficult. Conversely, the
            performance of the borrower was marginally satisfactory, in
            that, policy reforms and project actions, "owned'
            by the borrower, were accomplished with diligence and
            method. Regardless of the outcome, it is worth noting that
            most of the reform program was implemented, thus providing a
            positive impact for future rural sector development. The
            lessons learned show that project objectives need to be
            realistic, clearly defined, and above all, agreed upon with
            the borrower. Sector or sub-sector investment operations
            need a coherent focus on policy and institutional reforms,
            with increased participation by the borrower in its
            formulation. Systematic measures for development and impact
            indicators, need to be in place, specifically, at the design
            stage (mandatory in Bank projects since 1997). Procurement
            practices, disbursement procedures and auditing, need to be
            addressed early on, and explicitly agreed with the borrower.
            Finally, a sustained dialogue is paramount for a successful operation.
